shownText:
Arguing that the federal Defense of Marriage Act imposes serious administrative and financial costs on their operations, some of the nation’s largest companies filed a brief Wednesday with the Supreme Court , urging it to overturn a section of the act that denies federal benefits and recognition to same-sex couples.

The brief drew 278 signers, including more than 200 companies — among them Citigroup, Apple, Mars and Alcoa — as well as city governments and other groups.
In statements on Wednesday, many declared their firm opposition to discrimination based on sexual orientation.
But the brief focused more on the burdens imposed by the 1996 law on companies that offer benefits to same-sex spouses.

The brief is one of hundreds received by the court as it considers landmark cases on gay rights and marriage.
But with a wide swath of leading companies signing on, it was the latest sign of the rapid shift toward acceptance of same-sex marriage in the corporate world as well as in the country at large.
title: Companies Ask Justices to Overturn Gay Marriage Ban - NYTimes.com
